project.teaser: The main objective of HARMONISE is to provide an End-to-End interoperable & hierarchical solution to support, encourage and scale up the transformation of traditional districts to Positive Energy Districts (PEDs) through optimal design, management, and integration in an...
project.objective: The main objective of HARMONISE is to provide an End-to-End interoperable & hierarchical solution to support, encourage and scale up the transformation of traditional districts to Positive Energy Districts (PEDs) through optimal design, management, and integration in an interoperable, scalable, and replicable manner, following a user-centered approach, from the technology, business operation and social engagement perspectives, empowering the transition towards the European Super Grid . The consortium aims to offer a hierarchical approach, integrating, fog-enabled devices, co-simulation modules, open-standard interfaces, APIs, and open-standard System Structure and Parameterization (SSP) that will enable the connection with other tools and established networks. Additionally, a user engagement app will be presented to support the development of active business models, energy awareness and incentivize stakeholder involvement and entrepreneurship. Furthermore, the consortium plans to introduce a transactive energy approach via a blockchain-based network that allows dynamic and secure smart contracts and energy exchange. HARMONISE will support the management and expansion of multisectoral PEDs, including electricity and heating networks, RES integration, mobility schemes, and energy storage problems by unifying energy transactions. HARMONISE will be demonstrated in 4 physical pilots and 1 digital pilot case that will incorporate all the other cases to a super nova Grid.
project.title: Hierarchical and Agile Resource Management Optimization for Networks in Smart Energy Communities

article.title: Hierarchical and interoperable solutions for Positive Energy Districts

result.title: MAS-DR: An ML-Based Aggregation and Segmentation Framework for Residential Consumption Users to Assist DR Programs

details.authors: Petros Tzallas, Alexios Papaioannou, Asimina Dimara, Napoleon Bezas, Ioannis Moschos, Christos-Nikolaos Anagnostopoulos, Stelios Krinidis, Dimosthenis Ioannidis, Dimitrios Tzovaras

result.title: Smart Building Recommendations with LLMs: A Semantic Comparison Approach

details.authors: Ioannis Papaioannou, Christos Korkas, Elias Kosmatopoulos

result.title: HARMONISE Architecture
result.description: The project's ICT end-to-end architecture design based on the requirements (T1.1) and the use cases definition (T1.4), for the facilitation of the development tasks in WP2-4. The output will be a report that will follow the outcomes of T1.5 and will describe the technical and non technical specifications of HARMONISE platform architecture presenting information and figures related to components's development, communication protocols and others. Its outcome will be used internally by the task leaders of WP2-4 and externally by technology providers and research organizations interested on the technological framework of Harmonise project.

result.title: Standardisation Strategy
result.description: The development of a strategy to let the project effectively contribute to standardisation. The insights provided will ensure that the project's outcomes are not only aligned with but actively influencing the development of standards. The output will be report on these actions and will follow the outcomes of T6.6. Its outcome will be used internally by the task leaders of WP7-8 and externally by interested third parties such as standardization bodies. The two initial versions of the deliverable D6.7[a,b] are now merged with a due date on M12. D6.7c and D6.7d are set respectively as D7.5 in WP7 and D8.3 in WP8.

result.title: Simulation of Malfunctions in Home Appliances’ Power Consumption

details.authors: Alexios Papaioannou, Asimina Dimara, Christoforos Papaioannou, Ioannis Papaioannou, Stelios Krinidis, Christos-Nikolaos Anagnostopoulos, Christos Korkas, Elias Kosmatopoulos, Dimosthenis Ioannidis, Dimitrios Tzovaras

result.title: Project Website and Dissemination Plans
result.description: Development of a website for disseminating the project's activities. Another output will be a report on the activities for this webside. This deliverable will follow the results of T6.2 and its outcome will be used internally by the task leaders of WP6-8 and externally by interested third parties such as interested parties on Harmonise project. The Deliverable initially was labelled as D6.3.

result.title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Optimal EV Charging: A Multi-Level Framework for Dynamic Pricing and Load Scheduling

details.authors: Dimitrios G. Vamvakas, Christos D. Korkas, Christos D. Tsaknakis, Elias B. Kosmatopoulos
details.journalTitle: 2025 33rd Mediterranean Conference on Control and Automation (MED)

result.title: HARMONISE KPIs and evaluation metrics
result.description: A list of quantitive and qualitative KPIs for the evaluation of the 4+1 pilots of the project will be reported on this deliverable. The report will contain information on the list of technical, economic, environmental and social KPIs. The report will follow the outcomes of Task 1.3 and will be used internally by the task leaders of WP1-5 and externally by interested third parties such as research institutions involved in energy community projects, real estate developers and investors, local and national goverments and local residents.

result.title: Identification of regulations and barriers for interoperable Positive Energy Districts
result.description: The deliverable will present the investigation of factors, based on the PESTLE framework, that enable or hinder the transformation of energy districts into PEDs. The report will provide insights to the existing knowledge of PEDs, a list of their emerging requirements and a list of the identification of potential limiting factors to the development of PEDs. The report will follow the outcomes of Task 1.2. Its outcomes will be used internally by the task leaders of WP1-5 and externally by interested third parties such as standards, regulatory and goverment entitites, policy makers, energy utility companies, urban planning projects and financial and investing institutions.

result.title: Report on Business Model Definition
result.description: The design of the business models for the project to explore the business opportunities for PED. The output will be a report on this analysis based on both regulatory frameworks and market participation of PEDs. The report will follow the outcomes of T4.3 and its outcome will be used internally by the task leaders of WP7-8 and externally by interested third parties. The initial two versions (a,b) of deliverable D4.2 are set in the respective associated WPs. This deliverable corresponds to D4.2[a] associated to WP4. D4.2[b] is set as D5.4. in WP5.

result.title: Report on End-User and Stakeholder Requirements
result.description: The deliverable will be a report that will follow the outcomes of Task 1.1 and will present the research on the requirement definition, and an analysis study for defining the end-users' and stakeholders' requirements for facilitating the identification of different stakeholders' needs and their understanding on the expected benefits that arise from the optimising process. Its outcome will be used internally by the task leaders of WP1-5 and externally by interested third parties such as regulatory and government entities, PED managers, standards organizations and other energy community related projects.

result.title: Online and Adaptive PID Tuning for Thermal Zone Temperature Control with Bayesian Optimization

details.authors: Christos D. Tsaknakis, Christos D. Korkas, Dimitrios G. Vamvakas, Yiannis Boutalis, Elias B. Kosmatopoulos
details.journalTitle: 2025 33rd Mediterranean Conference on Control and Automation (MED)

result.title: HARMONISE Use Case analysis
result.description: The definition of use case scenarios based on information gathered from the relevant stakeholders at the use case sites, for validating and evaluating the use of the end-to-end interoperability platform will be reported on this deliverable. The output will be a report containing details about goals and targets of the foreseen use cases activities utilizing UML diagrams, end-user information and connection between the use cases and technical components. This report will follow the outcomes of T1.4 and will be used internally by the task leaders of WP1-5 and externally by interested third parties such as technology developers, research organizations and urban planning initiatives.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
